raw_text: We used the dataset introduced in Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) 4 and automatically converted their lambda-calculus expressions to attribute-value pairs following the conventions adopted by Liang et al (2009)
clean_text: We used the dataset introduced in Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) and automatically converted their lambda-calculus expressions to attribute-value pairs following the conventions adopted by Liang et al (2009).

raw_text: Following Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007), we trained on 4,962 scenarios and tested on ATIS NOV93 which contains 448 examples. Model Parameters Our model has two parameters, namely the number of k grammar derivations considered by the decoder and the order of the language model
clean_text: Following Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007), we trained on 4,962 scenarios and tested on ATIS NOV93 which contains 448 examples.

citing_paper_authors: James, Clarke | Dan, Goldwasser | Ming-Wei, Chang | Dan, Roth
raw_text: In order to provide an initial starting point, we initialize the weight vector using a similar procedure to the one used in (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007) to set weights for three features and a bias term
clean_text: In order to provide an initial starting point, we initialize the weight vector using a similar procedure to the one used in (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007) to set weights for three features and a bias term.

raw_text: This can create problems for applications based on CCG ,e.g. for the induction of stochastic CCGs from text annotated with logical forms (Zettlemoyerand Collins, 2007), where spreading probability mass over equivalent derivations should be avoided
clean_text: This can create problems for applications based on CCG, e.g. for the induction of stochastic CCGs from text annotated with logical forms (Zettlemoyerand Collins, 2007), where spreading probability mass over equivalent derivations should be avoided.

For example, Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) learn a mapping from textual queries to a logical form

raw_text: We evaluated GUSP on end-to-end question answering using the ATIS dataset for semantic parsing (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007)
clean_text: We evaluated GUSP on end-to-end question answering using the ATIS dataset for semantic parsing (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007).

raw_text: For example, Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) used a predicate from (f, c) to signify that flight f starts from city c. In the ATIS database, however, this amounts to a path of three joins :flight.from airport-airport airport-airport service airport service-city In GUSP, this is represented by the ed gestate flight-flight.from airport -airport-airport service-city
clean_text: For example, Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) used a predicate from (f, c) to signify that flight f starts from city c.

raw_text: Our starting point is the work done by Zettlemoyer and Collins on parsing using relaxed CCG grammars (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007) (ZC07)
clean_text: Our starting point is the work done by Zettlemoyer and Collins on parsing using relaxed CCG grammars (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007) (ZC07).

raw_text: Practically, the grammar relaxation is done via the introduction of non-standard CCG rules (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007)
clean_text: Practically, the grammar relaxation is done via the introduction of non-standard CCG rules (Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2007).

raw_text: We use the set developed by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007), which includes features that are sensitive to lexical choices and the structure of the logical form that is constructed
clean_text: We use the set developed by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007), which includes features that are sensitive to lexical choices and the structure of the logical form that is constructed.

raw_text: See the discussion by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) (ZC07) for the full details. Initialization and Parameters The CCG lexicon is hand engineered

citing_paper_authors: Chitta, Baral | Juraj, Dzifcak | Marcos Alvarez, Gonzalez | Jiayu, Zhou
raw_text: The systems that we compared with are: The SYN0, SYN20 and GOLDSYN systems by Ge and Mooney (2009), the system SCISSOR by Ge and Mooney (2005), an SVM based system KRIPS by Kate and Mooney (2006), a synchronous grammar based system WASP by Wong and Mooney (2007), the CCG based system by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) and the work by Lu et al (2008)
clean_text: The systems that we compared with are: The SYN0, SYN20 and GOLDSYN systems by Ge and Mooney (2009), the system SCISSOR by Ge and Mooney (2005), an SVM based system KRIPS by Kate and Mooney (2006), a synchronous grammar based system WASP by Wong and Mooney (2007), the CCG based system by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) and the work by Lu et al (2008).

raw_text: We make use of the standard application, composition and coordination combinators, as well as type-shifting rules introduced by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) to model spontaneous, unedited text
clean_text: We make use of the standard application, composition and coordination combinators, as well as type-shifting rules introduced by Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007) to model spontaneous, unedited text.

raw_text: We follow the setup of Zettlemoyerand Collins (2007) where possible, including feature design, initialization of the semantic parser, and evaluation metrics, as reviewed below. Features and Parser The features include indicators for lexical item use, properties of the logical form that is being constructed, and indicators for parsing operators used to build the tree
clean_text: We follow the setup of Zettlemoyerand Collins (2007) where possible, including feature design, initialization of the semantic parser, and evaluation metrics, as reviewed below.

citing_paper_authors: Gabor, Angeli | Christopher D., Manning | Daniel, Jurafsky
raw_text: The matching times can be thought of as analogous to the entities in a logical model which satisfy a given expression. Supervised approaches to logical parsing prominently include Zelle and Mooney (1996), Zettlemoyer and Collins (2005), Kate et al (2005), Zettlemoyer and Collins (2007), inter alia
